Bill X. Stafford, M.D. Chief, Transplant Divistion Department of Surgery Family Practice Missoula
Re: Peggy Tinsley FPM#: 236-67-03-3
Dear Dr. Stafford:
I was asked to provide a cardiologic evaluation on Mrs. Tinsley with a concentration on her appropriateness to be listed as a recipient for a cadaver renal transplant. In summary, she is a 46 year old woman who has been an insulin dependent diabetic since the age of 29 and has been on hemodialysis since 2083. By report, her other complications for diabetes include retinopathy, peripheral neuropathy, and peripheral vascular disease. In viewing her present history, she works in the Houghton Mifflin Harcourt learning technology department. Her three times a week hemodialyses are uncomplicated. She does, however, experience occasional chest pressure with activities and on rare occasions has had nocturnal angina. These episodes are relieved by nitroglycerin. Mrs. Tinsley has also noted that with walking she will occasionally get short of breath which is relieved by slowing down.
In addition to diabetes and hypertension which was present only pre-dialysis, she has been and continues to be a smoker. Her cholesterol by one report was 228 mg/dl. I don't have fractionations and her family history is unknown.
A report of an echocardiogram from April of 2083, shows mild ventricular hypertrophy in the presence of mitral insufficiency, preserved LV size and function. She had an exercise tolerance test in February of 2085. On a modified protocol, she went for less than 4 1/2 minutes. This is equivalent to not even completing stage 1 of the standard Bruce. With that, she did develop chest pain and had 2 mm of ST depression. That study was accompanied by both fixed and reversible isotopic perfusion changes in the septum consistent with prior non-transmural infarct with exercise induced ischemia. As was apparent to those involved, even the non-isotope portion alone was worrisome for high grade coronary disease and led to the recommendation for a cardiac catheterization.
That study was done in Macdonald Hospital and at this time, I only have the report. However, from this report, there was preserved LV function with anterior lateral hypokinesis and trace MR that is consistent with the echo and the thallium studies. Coronary angiography showed by report, diffuse involvement of proximal mid-LAD without specific focal stenosis until an 80% mid- LAD. The circumflex was also diffusely diseased and there was a discrete stenosis in the mid section of a large marginal. The right coronary artery was diffusely diseased with a discrete stenosis. At that time, the recommendation was to continue medical therapy.
Her medical therapy at this time is estrogen replacement with prempro 2.5 mg once a day, tenormin 25 mg qd, aspirin one every other day in addition to her supplemental vitamins, iron and twice daily insulin therapy.
In rounding out her medical history, her surgical procedures have involved the hemodialysis access. She has had one pregnancy 28 years ago without complications. I also elicited a history of some focal arm weakness and occasional slurring of speech. This was difficult to pin down, but is of some concern.
On exam, her blood pressure was 150/80 mm Hg, pulse 90 regular, her weight 95 lbs. Her hemodialysis shunt is on the left arm. There was a right carotid bruit, neck veins were not distended. Lungs were clear, PMI was displaced and sustained. There was an S4, no S3 and there was a holo systolic murmur at the apex. Abdomen was benign, femoral pulses were intact, extremities were without edema. The electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm, diffuse STT changes. There were no pathologic Q waves.
Although the focus of this evaluation was originally for transplant candidacy, I am concerned about her current cardiac status. She is a young diabetic woman, symptomatic of both shortness of breath and chest pain and on exercise test, has limited functional capacity. The coronary angiography reveals a presence of multi-vessel disease. Even without seeing the primary data which I hope to do in the next week, it would be unlikely that she would be an angioplasty candidate, given the poor results in diabetics. Therefore, coronary revascularization for her would be coronary artery bypass surgery.
Obviously, I would like to review the films first, and speak with Dr. Upson regarding augmentation of her anti-anginals. I would also like to add pravastatin at this time, starting with only 10 mg and obtain non-invasive studies of the carotids. As indicated, although the focus of this evaluation was her suitability for transplantation, the issue of controlling symptomatic coronary artery disease in this young woman became more pressing.
I look forward to working with you and the other physicians in her care.
Sincerely,
Quentin U. Johnson, M.D., Ph.D.
Quentin U. Johnson, M.D., Ph.D.
